title: On Collaboration (9/11 Anniversary)
mainTopics: Shared vision vs one person's vision

collaboration: Creating something they couldn't create separately
Not because of manpower but because of unique interaction
Change one person = fundamentally different result
Shared vision both can articulate the same way
Result named after the individuals/organizations involved
teamwork: Someone in charge, someone sets vision
Can swap people in same role without fundamental change

collaborationVsTeamwork.scottSkepticism: Rarely sees true collaboration - mostly teamwork or one person's vision with others getting on board
collaborationVsTeamwork.scottTest: If collaborators can't say what they're doing in the same way, maybe they're not actually collaborating

restaurant.collaboration: Head chef + restaurateur developing restaurant, menu, experience

filmmaking.teamwork: Hollywood roles - gaffer, best boy, grip - assigned roles, plug-and-play
filmmaking.collaboration: Mike Lee director inventing script with actors together
filmmaking.alsoCollaboration: Robert Icky & Andrew Scott choosing Hamlet then inventing the play together

uglyOranges.case: Management 101 negotiation - two teams need to buy last shipment of ugly oranges
uglyOranges.twist: One needs pith of peel (cancer serum), one needs juice
uglyOranges.solution: Pay $1 for shipment, split oranges, spend rest on research
uglyOranges.lesson: Investigate what each party actually needs - may be complementary not competitive

mikeNelson: Often 1 person does 80% of work, 4 people take all credit
Some of those 4 actually getting in the way, making silly suggestions, delaying
Skeptical of 'melding of minds' creating new organism
Need champion with deadline and motivation
Collaborations can wander and wander without deadline
Collaboration for collaboration's sake is problematic
kevinJones: Scott's definition: groups with own goals finding bridge between them
Kevin: 'I've never... I've done that a lot, and you get... you know, Barney, I like you, you like me, but nobody changes from their own goals'
Like ships passing, lower drawbridge briefly, but nobody diverts from their goal
Doesn't happen the way Scott's talking about it
skepticism.pattern: Practical skepticism - people who've attempted cross-organizational collaboration see limited success

wordDebate.gilConcern: Very problematic conversation - debating words we're using in different ways about meanings we aren't clear about
overlappingThings: Nature of human interaction for common purpose
Word labels we give to different types of interaction
wordDebate.gilExperience: Seems very different than Scott's - sees collaboration as far more common

frameworks.name: Collaboration vs Teamwork Distinction
frameworks.collaboration: Unique interaction of specific individuals creating novel result
frameworks.test: Can you swap one person without fundamentally changing the result?

frameworks.name: Ugly Oranges Negotiation Case
frameworks.setup: $1M budget, must buy last shipment of unique oranges, competing team
frameworks.solution: Discover complementary needs (pith vs juice), split oranges for $1, spend rest on research
frameworks.lesson: Investigate actual needs - apparent competition may be complementary goals

frameworks.name: Princess Bride Reference
frameworks.quote: You keep using that word. I don't think that means what you think that means
frameworks.usage: Scott's meme for organization culture buzzwords
frameworks.application: Collaboration used synonymously with 'let's get together and work'

frameworks.name: Etymology
frameworks.scottCritique: Ostensibly means anytime 2+ people doing something, but we're using it more narrowly

questionsRaised: How is collaboration different from teamwork?
How common is true collaboration (Scott's definition)?
When people ask for collaboration, do they really want it or just teamwork?
If collaborators can't articulate the same vision, are they collaborating?
Why do we use 'collaboration' for what's really teamwork?
Can cross-organizational groups with different goals truly collaborate?
How do we have productive conversations when we're using words differently?

participationNotes.Scott Moehring: Provocateur, arrived late, presented collaboration vs teamwork distinction, restaurant kitchen example, skeptical of collaboration claims
participationNotes.Jerry Michalski: Facilitator, Ugly Oranges case, Mike Lee film example, exploring Scott's distinction
participationNotes.Gil Friend: Challenged word debate, experience differs from Scott's, theater collaboration examples (Robert Icky/Andrew Scott Hamlet)
participationNotes.Kevin Jones: Explained Scott's definition re: cross-organizational goals, skeptical it works ('ships passing, lowering drawbridge')
participationNotes.Mike Nelson: Skeptical - 1 person does 80%, 4 take credit; need champion and deadline
participationNotes.Alex Kladitis: Present, noted others covered his points
participationNotes.Others: Present but not prominent in opening discussion

emotionalTone: Intellectual, definitional, some frustration with word debates (Gil), practical skepticism (Mike, Kevin), exploratory
specialNotes: Call on 9/11 anniversary - noted by Jerry
Jerry forgot to turn on recorder initially
Scott working during call (common pattern for him)
Princess Bride meme used to frame discussion
Gil's frustration with word debates echoes Call 05 sense-making discussion
Scott's distinction clear and specific - collaboration requires unique individuals, teamwork doesn't
Practical skepticism from people who've tried cross-organizational work (Kevin, Mike)
Gil sees collaboration as much more common than Scott does - different life experiences
crossCallThemes: Different life experiences leading to different views (echoes all calls)

connectionsToOtherCalls.call05: Gil's concern about debating words used differently directly echoes his 'what do we mean by sense?' challenge
connectionsToOtherCalls.call06: Kevin working on Swannanoa coordination - practical experience informs his skepticism about cross-organizational collaboration

metaObservations.definitionalClarity: Scott provided clearest definition debate so far - specific, testable distinction
metaObservations.experienceDivide: Scott/Kevin/Mike (skeptical from experience) vs Gil (sees it everywhere) - suggests context matters
metaObservations.practicalVsTheoretical: Skeptics have tried to do cross-organizational work, Gil may be seeing different type of collaboration
metaObservations.recursion: Discussion about collaboration demonstrated challenges of collaboration - different definitions, experiences, expectations
